description:
Complete refactor of volume rendering framework.  More details and updates to come. Obvious needs: documentation, documentation, documentation! Debugging Debugging Debugging!  

Update 1: Pushed changes that enable all VR cookbooks to run except vol-annotated.py, which I could use help on what direction we should take text annotation. Added lots of examples in volume_rendering/tests/, and updated some of the cookbooks and docstrings for the new Camera movement/rotation/etc. 

Current TODO list:

* Narrative Docs (Big)
* Updating API/Docstrings (Big)
* New examples of BoxSource, LineSource, OpaqueSource, and sc.composite(). (Medium)
* vol-annotated.py (Medium, need vision for text annotations)
* ~~Cookbooks for yt.off_axis_projection(), and yt.volume_render() (Easy)~~
* ~~Pull in (Stereo)SphericalCamera from old_camera.py (Medium)~~
* ~~Pull in new PerspectiveCamera from old_camera.py, and implement PerspectiveLens.project_to_plane (Medium)~~
* Implement StereoLens, and all other Lens objects I might be missing (Medium)
* ~~Someone should implement a very simple PointSource in render_source.py (Easy)~~
* I have no idea if camera_path.py needs to be touched. (Easy)
* Check all transfer functions (Easy)
title: Volume Rendering Refactor

content.raw:
Here's what Sam has suggested is a good approach:

1) Go through the vr cookbook examples, and the (non-nose style) tests in volume_rendering/tests, see if you like the way it works. 
2) Go through the volume_render function in volume_rendering.py, see if you like the way the code looks.
3) Figure out if the names of the classes/functions/methods make sense. For example, the main user-facing function is volume_render. it could be VolumeRender, VolumeRendering, VolumePlot, Plot3D, volume_rendering, create_volume_rendering, etc

content.raw:
Navigate to your yt repo and do

```
hg pull -r b597f07 https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt
hg up -C b597f07  # cleans your working dir, make sure you've shelved or committed any unsaved work
python setup.py develop
```

If you haven't updated in a while, you might need to update Cython with "pip install -U cython". You'll know there's an issue if the yt build fails complaining about a cython issue.
content.html:
Navigate to your yt repo and do

hg pull -r b597f07 https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt
hg up -C b597f07  # cleans your working dir, make sure you've shelved or committed any unsaved work
python setup.py develop

If you haven't updated in a while, you might need to update Cython with "pip install -U cython". You'll know there's an issue if the yt build fails complaining about a cython issue.

content.raw:
A few comments from the PR hangout, some from @chummels , some from others.  Sorry these aren't line-by-line.

 * `clip_ratio` should be changed to something more descriptive, and should be defaulted to something like 4.0
 * Default filename should be something more descriptive, like `PlotWindow` filenames default to
 * `map_to_colormap` has a `scale` keyword, which could be more descriptive or have examples
 * For camera, need docstrings for `set_lens`, `set_defaults_from_data_source`, `set_width`, `set_position`
 * The `__init__` method has the docstrings, but it would be nice to have them in the main class body
 * Longer examples, specifically calling out `PointsSource`
 * Change `resolution` to have a default in `off_axis_projection`, move it after `item`, change `item` to be `field`
 * Deprecate or remove `off_axis_projection`
 * `Scene` object has many stub docstrings
 * Fix method names to have them all be consistent for when looping over frames, something like `iterate_zoom` or something.
 * `Lens` has only stub docstrings
 * Transfer functions operate in log space for fields that are logged.  This should be done in the space of the fields.
 * `MultiVariate` and `Planck` transfer functions do not have documentation
 * `TransferFunctionHelper` should be split out into a different page
 * Put the annotations in the narrative docs to show how to do them.
 * `rotate` on the camera should specify what it is rotating -- specifically, it rotates the position of the camera
 * `switch_view` should be included in narrative docs
 * Add examples for all the different lenses
 * Make one parallelization header, with subheaders
 * Remove link to seismodome scripts (although they were based on scene refactor, @chummels says they can be confusing)
 * Note differences in ways to write images
 * Camera movement cookbook needs to be improved to make nice images
 * Link to subsections of the VR docs
 * LineSource takes `Nx3` positions, but it's done pairwise.  Make this do it more clearly by pairs.
 * Add narrative docs to get the source, camera, etc.
 * Possibly get rid of all getters other than for `source` on the scene object.
 * `get_source` is incorrect, since dicts are not sorted
 * Left handed versus right handed images; @chummels has code which demonstrates this problem.
content.html:

  • clip_ratio should be changed to something more descriptive, and should be defaulted to something like 4.0
  • Default filename should be something more descriptive, like PlotWindow filenames default to
  • map_to_colormap has a scale keyword, which could be more descriptive or have examples
  • For camera, need docstrings for set_lens, set_defaults_from_data_source, set_width, set_position
  • The __init__ method has the docstrings, but it would be nice to have them in the main class body
  • Longer examples, specifically calling out PointsSource
  • Change resolution to have a default in off_axis_projection, move it after item, change item to be field
  • Deprecate or remove off_axis_projection
  • Scene object has many stub docstrings
  • Fix method names to have them all be consistent for when looping over frames, something like iterate_zoom or something.
  • Lens has only stub docstrings
  • Transfer functions operate in log space for fields that are logged. This should be done in the space of the fields.
  • MultiVariate and Planck transfer functions do not have documentation
  • TransferFunctionHelper should be split out into a different page
  • Put the annotations in the narrative docs to show how to do them.
  • rotate on the camera should specify what it is rotating -- specifically, it rotates the position of the camera
  • switch_view should be included in narrative docs
  • Add examples for all the different lenses
  • Make one parallelization header, with subheaders
  • Remove link to seismodome scripts (although they were based on scene refactor, Cameron Hummels says they can be confusing)
  • Note differences in ways to write images
  • Camera movement cookbook needs to be improved to make nice images
  • Link to subsections of the VR docs
  • LineSource takes Nx3 positions, but it's done pairwise. Make this do it more clearly by pairs.
  • Add narrative docs to get the source, camera, etc.
  • Possibly get rid of all getters other than for source on the scene object.
  • get_source is incorrect, since dicts are not sorted
  • Left handed versus right handed images; Cameron Hummels has code which demonstrates this problem.

content.raw:
The error was originally documented [here](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/issue/758/vrs-are-transposed-relative-to-projections), but because the hub is no more, that's more of a placeholder now.

This [script](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5672/) demonstrates the problem, which is actually worse than it used to be.

Here is the [on-axis image](http://i.imgur.com/wKjTsNv.png) and the [off-axis image](http://i.imgur.com/rsKgl0C.png) which should be the same, but are very different.

In fact, you can see weirdness has happened in this PR branch relative to the main enzo-dev yt branch by looking at differences in the auto-generated docs images:

[This](http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/visualizing/plots.html#off-axis-projection-plots) is the page on OffAxisProjectionPlot results in the main enzo-dev docs.

[This](http://hub.yt:8080/job/yt_docs/76/artifact/sandbox/doc/build/html/visualizing/plots.html#off-axis-projection-plots) is the same page in the docs built for this PR.  Notice the change in images from the same script/data.
content.html:
The error was originally documented here, but because the hub is no more, that's more of a placeholder now.

This script demonstrates the problem, which is actually worse than it used to be.

Here is the on-axis image and the off-axis image which should be the same, but are very different.

In fact, you can see weirdness has happened in this PR branch relative to the main enzo-dev yt branch by looking at differences in the auto-generated docs images:

This is the page on OffAxisProjectionPlot results in the main enzo-dev docs.

This is the same page in the docs built for this PR. Notice the change in images from the same script/data.

None of the images produced in this recipe seem to render the underlying data, just the box edges, grids, and coords.  Not sure what is going on, but maybe because opacity is on it is blocking the underlying gas.   But this indicative that something is not working with the zbuffer here.

http://hub.yt:8080/job/yt_docs/76/artifact/sandbox/doc/build/html/cookbook/complex_plots.html#volume-rendering-with-bounding-box-and-overlaid-grids

and the grids are super faint.

I tried to get the opaque sources to work with non-opaque sources, and I'm having some problems. @samskillman : is this a known issue?  I seem to recall this was a problem a few months back, but I haven't kept up on it.  

As an example, I used the test involving `PointsSource` as a base to try to generate an image of a VR with some opaque points with some gas.  Whenever I include the opaque source, it seems to clobber and I lose out on the gas.  Does someone else have an example of this working? 

My failed attempt is [here](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5675/) which yields this [image](http://i.imgur.com/XElZECD.png) before we add points, and this [image](http://i.imgur.com/DcPp5Zb.png) after we add points.

content.raw:
I stoled a script from @mzingale and modified it for new refactor scheme -- which clearly reveals LHS/RHS issue. I think the system is in RHS, but just rotated.

```
#!python
import pylab
import yt
import numpy as np
import sys

N = 96

xmin = ymin = zmin = -1.0
xmax = ymax = zmax = 1.0

dcoord = (xmax - xmin)/N

arr = np.zeros((N,N,N), dtype=np.float64)
arr[:,:,:] = 1.e-4

bbox = np.array([ [xmin, xmax], [ymin, ymax], [zmin, zmax] ])

# coordinates -- in the notation data[i, j, k]
x = (np.arange(N) + 0.5)*(xmax - xmin)/N + xmin
y = (np.arange(N) + 0.5)*(ymax - ymin)/N + ymin
z = (np.arange(N) + 0.5)*(zmax - zmin)/N + zmin

x3d, y3d, z3d = np.meshgrid(x, y, z, indexing="ij")

# sphere at the origin
c = np.array( [0.5*(xmin + xmax), 0.5*(ymin + ymax), 0.5*(zmin + zmax) ] )

r = np.sqrt((x3d - c[0])**2 + (y3d - c[1])**2 + (z3d - c[2])**2)
arr[r < 0.05] = 1.0


# coordinate planes
ixy = np.logical_and(x3d > 0.0, y3d > 0.0)
iyz = np.logical_and(y3d > 0.0, z3d > 0.0)
ixz = np.logical_and(x3d > 0.0, z3d > 0.0)

arr[abs(x3d - xmin) < 2*dcoord] = 0.3
arr[abs(y3d - ymin) < 2*dcoord] = 0.3
arr[abs(z3d - zmin) < 2*dcoord] = 0.3

# single cube on +x
xc = 0.75
dx = 0.05
idx = np.logical_and(np.logical_and(x3d > xc-dx, x3d < xc+dx),
                     np.logical_and(np.logical_and(y3d > -dx, y3d < dx),
                                    np.logical_and(z3d > -dx, z3d < dx)) )

arr[idx] = 1.0


# two cubes on +y
dy = 0.05
for yc in [0.65, 0.85]:

    idx = np.logical_and(np.logical_and(y3d > yc-dy, y3d < yc+dy),
                         np.logical_and(np.logical_and(x3d > -dy, x3d < dy),
                                        np.logical_and(z3d > -dy, z3d < dy)) )

    arr[idx] = 0.8

# three cubes on +z
dz = 0.05
for zc in [0.5, 0.7, 0.9]:

    idx = np.logical_and(np.logical_and(z3d > zc-dz, z3d < zc+dz),
                         np.logical_and(np.logical_and(x3d > -dz, x3d < dz),
                                        np.logical_and(y3d > -dz, y3d < dz)) )

    arr[idx] = 0.6




data = dict(Density = arr)
ds = yt.load_uniform_grid(data, arr.shape, bbox=bbox)

from yt.visualization.volume_rendering.api import Scene, Camera, VolumeSource, \
                                                  ColorTransferFunction

sc = Scene()
cam = Camera(ds, lens_type='perspective')
cam.position = ds.arr(np.array([-4.,0.,0.]), 'code_length')
cam.switch_orientation(normal_vector=[1.,0.,0.],
                       north_vector=[0.,0.,1.])
cam.set_width(ds.domain_width*4.)

vol = VolumeSource(ds, field=('gas', 'Density'))

tf = vol.transfer_function
tf = ColorTransferFunction((0.1,1.0))
tf.sample_colormap(1.0, 0.01, colormap="coolwarm")
tf.sample_colormap(0.8, 0.01, colormap="coolwarm")
tf.sample_colormap(0.6, 0.01, colormap="coolwarm")
tf.sample_colormap(0.3, 0.01, colormap="coolwarm")

sc.camera = cam
sc.add_source(vol)
sc.render('test_perspective.png', clip_ratio=6.0)
```

![test_perspective.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/971533176-test_perspective.png)

cam = Camera(ds, lens_type='perspective')
cam.position = ds.arr(np.array([-4.,0.,0.]), 'code_length')

content.raw:
I'm a bit confused.  Is the `normal_vector` pointing from the camera to the focus? or from the focus to the camera? If it goes from the focus to the camera, just as the `north_vector` goes from the focus to the "north" then I think we're in a LHS as the x vector is pointing outward toward us from the image plane, the y vector is going east, and the z vector is going south.

But given the fact that the camera location is at [-4, 0, 0] and the `normal_vector` is set to +x, in order for us to actually see anything, it means that the `normal_vector` is going from the camera to the focus (ie into the image frame from the viewer).  In that case, I guess it means that we're in a RHS with the +y vector going east and the +z vector going south.

content.raw:
The ```normal_vector``` in (stereo) perspective/spherical lens  is from camera to focus, and I believe in plane-parallel lens it's the same.

I've used the same script-generated data to make an off-axis projection plot and a plane-parallel plot. The results are, the off-axis projection are in LHS and agrees with on-axis projection plot; the plane-parallel lens gives same orientation with perspective/spherical, which are in RHS with the +y vector going east and the +z vector going south.

content.raw:
OK, I think I have figured out the problem.  The VR system measure the normal vector from the camera, as we've already figured out, but in the PlotWindow interface, there is no "camera" per se, and the normal vector is measured from the `focus`.  So they're both in a RHS from their own perspective, but it's because that normal vector is getting reversed between the two systems.

To further cement this, I ran a new script showing the PW results alongside the VR results with the same normal_vector and north_vector values.  You can see that by reversing the value of the north_vector (to use -z), it forces the east vector to go from y to -y because its in a RHS.  If we just internally swap the z vector to be -z as you earlier suggested, it would switch it to be a LHS from the perspective of the camera, but it would be a RHS from the perspective of the focus (ie the center), which is what PW does, and I think what is "right" here.


```
#!python

import yt
import numpy as np

ds = yt.load("enzo_cosmology_plus/RD0007/RD0007")
x_vec = [1,0,0]
z_vec = [0,0,1]
reverse_z_vec = [0,0,-1]

# On axis projection, normal vec is x, east vec is -y, north vec is z
yt.ProjectionPlot(ds, 'x', 'density').save('on.png')

# Off axis projection, normal vec is x, east vec is -y, north vec is z
yt.OffAxisProjectionPlot(ds, x_vec, 'density',
                         north_vector=z_vec).save('off.png')

# VR
im, sc = yt.volume_render(ds, field=('gas', 'density'))
cam = sc.camera
cam.set_width(ds.domain_width)
cam.switch_orientation(normal_vector=x_vec,
                       north_vector=z_vec)
sc.render('vr.png', clip_ratio=4.0)
cam.switch_orientation(normal_vector=x_vec,
                       north_vector=reverse_z_vec)
sc.render('vr_reverse_z.png', clip_ratio=4.0)
```

Which yields these images: [off.png](http://i.imgur.com/qpDrbmD.png), [vr.png](http://i.imgur.com/giV0MhF.png), and [vr_reverse_z.png](http://i.imgur.com/bIYc1aD.png).

The VR system measure the normal vector from the camera, as we've already figured out, but in the PlotWindow interface, there is no "camera" per se, and the normal vector is measured from the focus. So they're both in a RHS from their own perspective, but it's because that normal vector is getting reversed between the two systems.

To further cement this, I ran a new script showing the PW results alongside the VR results with the same normal_vector and north_vector values. You can see that by reversing the value of the north_vector (to use -z), it forces the east vector to go from y to -y because its in a RHS. If we just internally swap the z vector to be -z as you earlier suggested, it would switch it to be a LHS from the perspective of the camera, but it would be a RHS from the perspective of the focus (ie the center), which is what PW does, and I think what is "right" here.

content.raw:
Here are my thoughts to the above list. Many of these are items that, in my opinion, do not need to be part of this PR, and honestly adding more changes to this is just making things more difficult to track. Therefore, I'd strongly suggest that we keep additional new features/API changes out of the PR. Sounds like 3.2 will drop soon, so maybe this could go in immediately afterwards and have a couple month shakedown by folks before a 3.3. In any case, I'm going to mark changes that I don't think are necessary before merge as NNBM.

* clip_ratio should be changed to something more descriptive, and should be defaulted to something like 4.0 - NNBM
* Default filename should be something more descriptive, like PlotWindow filenames default to - NNBM
* map_to_colormap has a scale keyword, which could be more descriptive or have examples - NNBM, probably just needs a better name
* For camera, need docstrings for set_lens, set_defaults_from_data_source, set_width, set_position -- I think this is done now.
* The __init__ method has the docstrings, but it would be nice to have them in the main class body -- NNBM, and partly done.
* Longer examples, specifically calling out PointsSource -- NNBM. The new docstrings help, too.
* Change resolution to have a default in off_axis_projection, move it after item, change item to be field -- See the PR for my thoughts.
* Deprecate or remove off_axis_projection -- I disagree with this pretty wholeheartedly
* Scene object has many stub docstrings -- I think many of these are fixed now.
* Fix method names to have them all be consistent for when looping over frames, something like iterate_zoom or something. -- See PR notes, I think just needs a different destination bookmark.
* Lens has only stub docstrings -- Most if not all are done now.
* Transfer functions operate in log space for fields that are logged. This should be done in the space of the fields.  -- Matt is working on this. This is definitely a stumbling point in the code.
* MultiVariate and Planck transfer functions do not have documentation -- I don't think they have in quite a while. NNBM
* TransferFunctionHelper should be split out into a different page -- NNBM
* Put the annotations in the narrative docs to show how to do them. -- NNBM
* rotate on the camera should specify what it is rotating -- specifically, it rotates the position of the camera -- Does this just need docs?
* switch_view should be included in narrative docs -- NNBM
* Add examples for all the different lenses -- NNBM, and it'd be much easier to review the examples separately, especially since folks other than me use the other ones more regularly.
* Make one parallelization header, with subheaders -- Done
* Remove link to seismodome scripts (although they were based on scene refactor, Cameron Hummels says they can be confusing) -- Done
* Note differences in ways to write images -- Where? Are the API docs for the ImageArray not good enough?
* Camera movement cookbook needs to be improved to make nice images -- NNBM
* Link to subsections of the VR docs -- I think this happened, but not sure. Any additional links can come after the merge.
* LineSource takes Nx3 positions, but it's done pairwise. Make this do it more clearly by pairs. -- Done
* Add narrative docs to get the source, camera, etc. -- Done? Not sure.
* Possibly get rid of all getters other than for source on the scene object. -- NNBM
* get_source is incorrect, since dicts are not sorted -- Done
* Left handed versus right handed images; Cameron Hummels has code which demonstrates this problem. -- A problem that I assume will never be fixed for more than 6 months at a time.

content.raw:
I guess the question is: what is the goal in getting a PR into the dev branch?  Is it so that people have access to it, who can then test it out, and the API will change before it goes into stable? Is it to unblock other functionality like unstructured mesh? Is it to get a mostly-set API in place with fleshed out functionality so people can use it and use the docs to figure out how to use it?

I understand the desire to get this out, because it's holding up other things, but we've run into problems like this in the past.  Once the PR is accepted, any additional things that need to be done (documentation, testing) rarely gets done because there is no impetus to do it.  Furthermore, it seems problematic to have a major break in the API in accepting this PR, only to then break the API in subsequent PRs immediately afterwards.  In fact, it was already noted that we shouldn't even change the API *now* inside this PR because there are ~5 people who have used this functionality.  It will be 1e6 times harder to change it when it's in the main dev repo and there are hundreds of users using it.

I know everyone sees docs as a pain in the ass, but ultimately the point of documentation in the form of cookbooks, docstrings, and narrative docs is to make it so that people who are unfamiliar with this functionality able to use it effectively.  If we release this to the community prior to sufficient documentation, we're just making our work harder, because people will (1) spent extra time trying to figure out how to make it work; (2) get frustrated with yt as a whole because they cannot find docs or get this to work; and (3) email/slack/irc/private-message us until we make it work *or* just give up on VR or yt in general.  In fact, as someone who *is* familiar with many of the changes in the VR refactor, *I* had problems getting some of the new functionality to work, and got frustrated too.  Just think about how difficult it will be for someone who is new to this VR refactor, or worse, new to yt in general.  

The main feedback we received in the last user survey after the release of 3.0 was for problems in the documentation, particularly in the move from 2.x to 3.x due to so many changes and insufficient docs noting these changes.  I can see this becoming an issue again if this PR is merged with minimal changes as suggested above.

Furthermore, it isn't just a matter of documentation, API, and testing, there appears to be broken functionality. The LineSource and PointSource stuff basically doesn't work as is because the alpha values are not balanced as shown in the cookbook example.  The cookbook demonstrating moving the camera around shows weird artifacts in the resulting image, which we should figure out before we release it, no?  I think the left-handed right-handed problems are finally figured out (thanks to @jisuoqing), and we should address this before merging.  We're very close, and I'd hate to have made it 90% of the way to having this be finished and then just merge it now.

While I agree with some of the notes above by Sam, I must disagree on the majority of them being NNBM.

content.raw:
I want to weigh in on this as someone who has been largely not involved in this PR.

I think it's quite clear that this functionality has a long way to go before it can be included in a stable release.  Even if it's just documentation that's missing, we simply cannot consider releasing this until it is completely finished.  However, there is precedent for pulling large PRs into an "experimental" bookmark in the main repo to allow for easier group development.  We did this for much of what went into yt-3.0 before it was released.  Additionally, we need to consider the burden that has been placed on @samskillman (whose time to continue working on this is extremely limited) by requiring that all development and PRs occur in his fork.  I think we should strongly consider making use of an experimental bookmark and allowing this work to live there instead of in @samskillman's fork.

This of course complicates the development process as there will be three heads to maintain and keep concurrent with bugfixes.  In theory, @MatthewTurk is now meant to be in charge of seeing that bugfixes are properly transplanted between branches.  If he can keep on top of this duty, then I think this is doable.

Again, I do not think this can be included in any stable release until it is totally done, but we need to consider if the current development process can be improved.

content.raw: I think there's simpler solution than separate head. We can make sure that `api` module exposes old interface. The new one will be accessible only if explictly imported. This way it can stay hidden from users and development will be much easier.

content.raw:
I agree with @brittonsmith's points here. We are obviously not going to get this in before 3.2, nor should there be any sweat about that. 

I think that it's fine to put this in an experimental bookmark, but I have to disagree with @chummels just a bit here about the consequences of merging it after the 3.2 release into dev. If anything, merging into dev (or at the very least an experimental bookmark of dev) is the only certain way to make sure that it gets adequately tested before it gets included in a stable release, since we won't know if it covers corner cases until it's at least somewhat out in the open. Sure, people can pull and merge @samskillman's fork, but that's too much of an extra step for a lot of people. 

"dev" _should_ mean "in development", meaning that things are not quite complete, there may be bugs, and we won't have complete documentation yet. That doesn't mean it should be the wild west, but I think the argument has been adequately made that for this specific case we are nearing a point where adding much more to this PR would be detrimental to giving this functionality a proper review.

content.raw: My issue with this is that once it's on the same head as the mainline of development, we are prevented from doing any more stable releases until this is done.  If momentum builds for another release and this is not finished, there will always be the temptation to "just let it in" and get to the rest of the to-do list later.  Not only do we know how that story ends, we have seen the friction that this debate has caused and I really think we should not go back there again.

content.raw:
I've played with the new VR a bit, and it shows promise, but it is not yet ready for my workflow.  I want to find time to pitch in more.  My view is to release 3.2 ASAP and then merge the new VR into development so it can get more eyes on it.  I think that is fair, as John notes, since development means development.

I like Kasper's suggestion too -- I'm happy with that. 

In an ideal world 3.3 would be the first with the new VR with the old one still exposed through a different API, and then come 4.0, the old one is dropped.  We need to give people time to move their scripts to the new VR and then time to knock out whatever bugs creep in.

content.raw:
I think all of the questions Cameron mentions are pluses to getting this in dev after the 3.2 release. We won't know whether the documentation and API we have is good enough until there is a trial period of people trying to use it, and getting this into dev facilitates that. 

I'm in 100% agreement that we need full documentation and a fixed API before this code gets included in a stable release. The only point of disagreement is, do we need to meet the same standards before we merge the changes into dev, as well? I think it's reasonable to expect that the development branch will contain features that are in beta and might undergo API changes and/or not meet the same standards of documentation. 

I admittedly wasn't around during the transition from 2.X to 3.0, so I'm not really up on the history there, but why can't we just agree here and now that there will be no 3.3 release until the scene refactor is 100% ready?

content.raw: I think we absolutely need the same standard because the fact of the matter is everyone hates writing docs and everyone here is busy enough that it will immediately fall to the bottom of the priority list once there is no deadline to meet.  Every major release we have ever done has required an exhausting sprint to finish docs at the last minute and it has resulted in increased tensions, burnout, and hurt feelings.  By keeping things in a separate head, we allow releases to continue to happen and avoid the above situation.

So we have to chart a middle course of some sort between merging it into dev on the one hand and letting it sit in Sam's fork and grow on the other.
